summary.topic: it's important to make your designs both beautiful and usable
summary.summary: i grew up in a family of designers, with both my mom and dad in the field. from a young age, i learned that providing a holistic end-to-end experience is crucial, no matter what.

summary.topic: design involves the holistic experience from end to end
summary.summary: designed houses and communities go beyond just looking beautiful; the meticulous attention to every detail ensures usability. today, we'll cover how great design isn't just about aesthetics, but also functionality. the best designs work as a whole.

summary.topic: useful, usable, and beautiful are key elements of great design
summary.summary: usefulness, usability, and aesthetics form the holy trinity of design. a design might be useful but not very usable or visually pleasing. you always start with making it useful.

summary.topic: start by making sure your design is useful
summary.summary: it should solve a problem for the user and meet their needs. if it's not useful, it doesn't matter how usable or beautiful it is. nail that part first and everything else will follow.

summary.topic: then ensure the design is usable; don't complicate it
summary.summary: make it simple and easy to use. people shouldn't need to solve a puzzle or mystery like in the da vinci code to figure things out. they found something useful; now they just want to use it without a struggle.

summary.topic: all these principles can apply to any domain
summary.summary: usability is crucial in all domains, whether it's web design, app design, music, videos, films, or art. if something is difficult to use, people will simply abandon it. this applies universally, emphasizing the importance of making everything user-friendly.

summary.topic: monitor user interactions to assess usability
summary.summary: your analytics will plummet if you put out a trash video that no one interacts with, even if it's aesthetically pleasing. it's a sign that maybe the content wasn't useful or insightful enough. ultimately, good design matters, but usefulness is key.

summary.topic: finally, make the design aesthetically pleasing without sacrificing usability
summary.summary: deciding what to wear depends on your intention and how you want to be perceived. it's an iterative process, and different for everyone. prioritize making your outfit useful and usable, and the aesthetics will come naturally. don't get hung up on the tools; just start and iterate from there.

summary.topic: focus on starting with something familiar and optimize it
summary.summary: don't obsess over which framework to use; just start with something familiar, like cap cut. if you spend too much time deciding, you'll lose valuable weeks you could have spent getting feedback. starting with anything is better than wasting time overthinking.

summary.topic: overthinking the tools can hinder progress
summary.summary: start with something you're comfortable with, ideally something you already know how to use. for me, that's pen and paper. we were in mexico city about 18 months ago, brainstorming the next chapter for bill space, and pen and paper made it easy to iron out ideas.

summary.topic: use a comfortable tool to get started quickly
summary.summary: so, right then, I asked my team for their opinion, showed them a quick sketch, got their feedback, and moved on within 15 minutes. instead of spending days on figma, I chose a faster approach, avoiding past mistakes of overworking in my early 20s.

summary.topic: for instance, pen and paper can be very effective
summary.summary: don't be afraid to share your work before it's finished. people follow you for the journey, not just the final product. if you only show the end result, you rob your audience of the full experience.

summary.topic: feedback cycles are crucial for improvement
summary.summary: his journey has ups and downs, and his audience is like a film audience subscribing to his story. don't overcomplicate things; break them down into manageable steps, like scaling unscalable mountains. use tools like excal, a digital canvas for rough sketches, to map out ideas simply and effectively before jumping into more complex design software.

summary.topic: share your journey, not just the destination, with your audience
summary.summary: there are various blocks you can use along with flowcharts to visualize user interactions. these tools help you see the user journey clearly.

summary.topic: know your user’s needs and design should cater to them specifically
summary.summary: the landing page showed users how to handle their username and other basics quickly. despite receiving feedback and iterating, the shipped product was flawed and rushed but completed in just two weeks.

summary.topic: it's better to create and iterate quickly than to perfect each iteration
summary.summary: don't waste time making things perfect in figma; it's not worth it. we learned a lot just by going through the process a few times. any questions? this will be quick since most of you already know these basics.

summary.topic: use simple design models like 'chats' to maintain aesthetics
summary.summary: it's not trademarked, but my own thing called chats. for those new to it, chats stands for color and contrast. simple.

summary.topic: great design involves good color contrast, hierarchy, alignment, typography, and spacing
summary.summary: right, once you have a useful and usable design, make it aesthetic by following a simple framework for color contrast. why is it hard to read? some students found it challenging, and honestly, it looked ugly. our generation is so internet native, we've developed a good eye for design just by consuming a lot of content. be intentional and notice what catches your eye and stops your scroll.

summary.topic: it's important to be intentional with design choices
summary.summary: take a moment to think about what got you hooked, then keep doom scrolling but like

summary.topic: consistent yet evolving designs capture user trust
summary.summary: don't rob yourself of self-reflection. fix the contrast, and the whole thing looks better. play around with it to get a good result. cool, hierarchy super.

summary.topic: examples of good design can be inspiration but should not restrict creativity
summary.summary: viewers will generally default to reading top-down, left-right unless specified otherwise, like in Arabic countries which is right-left. keep design simple with clear alignment, intentional typography (limit typefaces), and proper spacing between elements. consistency is key in design to create brand recognition. understand basic principles and build on them creatively for impactful designs.

summary.topic: intentional content consumption helps form better design ideas
summary.summary: startups and big companies like Apple spend months on projects with large teams, but we had two weeks and five people. we had to find ways to streamline processes, using previous experience and tools we're comfortable with to save time. for instance, I quickly mocked up an animation in Framer and passed it to a friend for refinement, focusing on efficiency rather than investing excessive time. the goal is that any of you can do this by trusting your methods and using what you know best, even under time constraints.

summary.topic: trust in your process and methods to produce high-quality work efficiently
summary.summary: lib is one of the greatest producers ever, using just an ipad and garage band for the last 10 years, which blows my mind given his level of mastery. for me, framer is that tool now, combining figma and webflow into one perfect platform, streamlining my process and allowing me to focus on creativity. the key takeaway is to start finding a process you can trust and keep refining it over time.

summary.topic: consistent, small improvements will refine design processes over time
summary.summary: chiseling away at this process helps you become the best version of the artist you're aiming to be over time. don't fall in love with the tools; know who you're building for. the success of apps like Netflix versus certain apps in China, which thrive on microtransactions, shows how crucial it is to understand your audience and cater to their specific needs and habits.

summary.topic: aim for iteration in design rather than perfection from the start
summary.summary: losing trust in you comes from pushing new products every day, so be consistent and know your audience. be authentic, don't aim for perfection—aim for iteration. in a photography class, students tasked with taking a photo daily, regardless of quality, produced far better photos than those aiming for one perfect shot. post content that's worth bookmarking and easy to understand at a glance.

summary.topic: cross-posting content can help reach larger audiences with less effort
summary.summary: to increase views, start with an eye-catching thumbnail and title. since people are searching for bubble apps, optimize your title, description, and thumbnail. crosspost on various platforms like bubble, reddit, and hacker news to create more entry points for viewers. ab test different versions to see what works best. it's minimal effort for potentially significant payoff, so don't miss out.

summary.topic: start with basic tools and methods you are familiar with to save time
summary.summary: if you buy one Powerball ticket for $2, it's standard, but for $5, you get eight tickets—spend a bit more for better odds. the internet is like a giant lottery; posting content on multiple platforms increases your chances, similar to buying more tickets. this approach, akin to the scarcity model, is about maximizing opportunities with minimal extra effort, just like mastering steps as a baby.

summary.topic: don’t worry about failing; focus on getting better with each step
summary.summary: a baby learning to walk is like comparing themselves to usain bolt, thinking they'll never get there. but it’s okay to fall and get laughed at; just get back up, lean on others for support, and keep trying until you can eventually walk on your own. everyone around you is there to help.

summary.topic: test and gather feedback to continually improve your design process
summary.summary: we're here to help you take the first steps. if you overthink what it takes to be great like your idols, it'll paralyze you. don't worry about achieving their heights yet; just focus on starting.

summary.topic: don't let overthinking about established excellence paralyze your progress
summary.summary: take your first steps and stop overthinking. thanks to cat, karen, and somaya for their help. overall, the video met expectations, with a great audience response; now it's time to focus on the next ones. any questions?
